elements.content: Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic–organic hybrid materials, [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2, pytpy = 4′-(4-pyridyl)-4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine), have been prepared by in situ formation of the Mo4O13 2– clusters from the decomposition of H3PMo12 under hydrothermal conditions. Both of the two complexes display three-dimensional (3D) “pillar-layer” frameworks based on bimetal-oxide layers pillared by the pytpy ligands. Topological analysis revealed that two 3D frameworks can be simplified into (3,4,4)-connected (42.62.83)2(4.62)2(44.102) and (3,5,6)-connected (42.6)2(44.66)2(44.68.83) topologies with the metal ions as nodes, respectively. Importantly, good photocatalytic activities were observed for both complexes in the photodecomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic-organic hybrid materials, [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2, pytpy = 4'-(4-pyridyl)-4,2':6',4"-terpyridine), have been prepared by in situ formation of the Mo4O13 2- clusters from the decomposition of H3PMo12 under hydrothermal conditions. Both of the two complexes display three-dimensional (3D) "pillar-layer" frameworks based on bimetal-oxide layers pillared by the pytpy ligands. Topological analysis revealed that two 3D frameworks can be simplified into (3,4,4)-connected (42.62.83)2(4.62)2(44.102) and (3,5,6)-connected (42.6)2(44.66)2(44.68.83) topologies with the metal ions as nodes, respectively. Importantly, good photocatalytic activities were observed for both complexes in the photodecomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV light irradiation.

elements.content: Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic−organic hybrid materials have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Both of the complexes present three-dimensional (3D) “pillar-layer” frameworks based on bimetal-oxide layers pillared by the pytpy ligands. Topological analysis reveals that two 3D frameworks can be simplified into (3,4,4)- and (3,5,6)-connected net with the metal ions as nodes, respectively. Importantly, the two complexes, especially for 2, show good photocatalytic activities for the decomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic-organic hybrid materials have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Both of the complexes present three-dimensional (3D) "pillar-layer" frameworks based on bimetal-oxide layers pillared by the pytpy ligands. Topological analysis reveals that two 3D frameworks can be simplified into (3,4,4)- and (3,5,6)-connected net with the metal ions as nodes, respectively. Importantly, the two complexes, especially for 2, show good photocatalytic activities for the decomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV light irradiation.

elements.content: As a unique class of metal–oxide clusters, polyoxometalates (POMs) have aroused considerable attention in many fields covering catalysis, magnetism, biological activity, optics, electrical conductivity, and others. Polyoxomolybdate (Mo-POM) is a remarkable family of POMs with versatile stoichiometry, diversified structure, and high reactivity, which have received much attention. Recently, an important advance and challenge in Mo-POM chemistry is the modification of Mo-POM with organic ligands and transition metal coordination complexes or fragments, which is expected to achieve POMs-based inorganic–organic hybrids with unique structural features and certain functions. Zubieta and co-workers have studied the structure directing role of organoamine ligands in the self-assembly of bimetallic oxide-based solid materials. According to this strategy, the introduction of new ligand systems and secondary metal ions into Mo-POM inorganic microstructures will give complete and deep knowledge of the structure–function relationship of these hybrid materials. Therefore, the rational design and synthesis of multifunctional molybdate-based hybrids is still a challenging issue.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a unique class of metal-oxide clusters, polyoxometalates (POMs) have aroused considerable attention in many fields covering catalysis, magnetism, biological activity, optics, electrical conductivity, and others. Polyoxomolybdate (Mo-POM) is a remarkable family of POMs with versatile stoichiometry, diversified structure, and high reactivity, which have received much attention. Recently, an important advance and challenge in Mo-POM chemistry is the modification of Mo-POM with organic ligands and transition metal coordination complexes or fragments, which is expected to achieve POMs-based inorganic-organic hybrids with unique structural features and certain functions. Zubieta and co-workers have studied the structure directing role of organoamine ligands in the self-assembly of bimetallic oxide-based solid materials. According to this strategy, the introduction of new ligand systems and secondary metal ions into Mo-POM inorganic microstructures will give complete and deep knowledge of the structure-function relationship of these hybrid materials. Therefore, the rational design and synthesis of multifunctional molybdate-based hybrids is still a challenging issue.

elements.content: The oxomolybdenums of chain structures, with the general formula of [Mo x O y ] n−, are an important kind of polyoxomolybdate. However, by comparison with a great number of the molybdenum oxide clusters which are structurally modified by incorporating transition metal complexes or organic ligands, the solid materials containing a decorated one-dimensional (1D) oxomolybdenum chain are relatively less explored. Furthermore, to our knowledge, the organic ligands as templates connected by both molybdenum and the second metal atoms simultaneously are rare in inorganic–organic molybdate oxide-based hybrids, especially for those with 1D oxomolybdenum chain based complexes.
elements.clean_text: The oxomolybdenums of chain structures, with the general formula of [Mo x O y ] n-, are an important kind of polyoxomolybdate. However, by comparison with a great number of the molybdenum oxide clusters which are structurally modified by incorporating transition metal complexes or organic ligands, the solid materials containing a decorated one-dimensional (1D) oxomolybdenum chain are relatively less explored. Furthermore, to our knowledge, the organic ligands as templates connected by both molybdenum and the second metal atoms simultaneously are rare in inorganic-organic molybdate oxide-based hybrids, especially for those with 1D oxomolybdenum chain based complexes.

elements.content: With the well-defined redox waves and light absorption band-edge positions, POMs have been applied in electrocatalysis and photocatalysis for the removal of organic pollutants or toxic metal salts from water. It is particularly well-known that many molybdate-based salts that contain organoammonium ligands and transition metal coordination complexes readily undergo photoredox-reactions in the solid state. These composite materials can not only enrich the frameworks of molybdate oxide-based hybrids but also ameliorate their electronic property. Meanwhile, they are good candidates for the catalytic applications owing to their structural rigidity. However, high solubility in aqueous solution restricts their potential application in wastewater treatment, because of the difficulty in their recovering and recycling. Therefore, the design and synthesis of water-insoluble molybdate oxide-based catalysis materials involving introduction of organic molecules and heterometals is an important challenge. Herein, we present two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic–organic hybrid materials based on heterometal-oxide layers, [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2, pytpy = 4′-(4-pyridyl)-4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine), which not only exhibit interesting topology structures but also are good electro- and photocatalysts.
elements.clean_text: With the well-defined redox waves and light absorption band-edge positions, POMs have been applied in electrocatalysis and photocatalysis for the removal of organic pollutants or toxic metal salts from water. It is particularly well-known that many molybdate-based salts that contain organoammonium ligands and transition metal coordination complexes readily undergo photoredox-reactions in the solid state. These composite materials can not only enrich the frameworks of molybdate oxide-based hybrids but also ameliorate their electronic property. Meanwhile, they are good candidates for the catalytic applications owing to their structural rigidity. However, high solubility in aqueous solution restricts their potential application in wastewater treatment, because of the difficulty in their recovering and recycling. Therefore, the design and synthesis of water-insoluble molybdate oxide-based catalysis materials involving introduction of organic molecules and heterometals is an important challenge. Herein, we present two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic-organic hybrid materials based on heterometal-oxide layers, [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2, pytpy = 4'-(4-pyridyl)-4,2':6',4"-terpyridine), which not only exhibit interesting topology structures but also are good electro- and photocatalysts.

elements.content: All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were used as supplied from commercial sources. The ligand pytpy and H3PMo12 were synthesized according to the literatures. Elemental analysis of C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer with a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 from ambient temperature to 800 °C under nitrogen gas. UV–vis absorption spectra were measured with a Hitachi U-3010 UV–vis spectrophotometer. The specific surface area was performed using an ASAP 2020 M gas adsorption analyzer. Photocatalytic experiment was carried out on an OCRS-I apparatus.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were used as supplied from commercial sources. The ligand pytpy and H3PMo12  were synthesized according to the literatures. Elemental analysis of C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer with a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from ambient temperature to 800 °C under nitrogen gas. UV-vis absorption spectra were measured with a Hitachi U-3010 UV-vis spectrophotometer. The specific surface area was performed using an ASAP 2020 M gas adsorption analyzer. Photocatalytic experiment was carried out on an OCRS-I apparatus.

elements.content: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.2 mg), H3PMo12·xH2O (∼0.05 mmol,100 mg), and pytpy (0.2 mmol, 62 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The pH value was adjusted to 2.6–3.2 with 1 M NaOH solution, and then the mixture was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon reactor autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, blue needle crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. Yield: ∼40% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Cu (1276.00): C, 37.65; H, 2.21; N, 8.78%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.48; N, 8.53%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3044m, 2455w, 1934w, 1600s, 1531s, 1401s, 1318w, 1216s, 922s, 825s, 695s, 531s.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2)

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.2 mg), H3PMo12⋅xH2O (~0.05 mmol,100 mg), and pytpy (0.2 mmol, 62 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The pH value was adjusted to 2.6-3.2 with 1 M NaOH solution, and then the mixture was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon reactor autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, blue needle crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. Yield: ~40% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Cu (1276.00): C, 37.65; H, 2.21; N, 8.78%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.48; N, 8.53%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3044m, 2455w, 1934w, 1600s, 1531s, 1401s, 1318w, 1216s, 922s, 825s, 695s, 531s.

elements.content: The preparation procedure of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) was used instead of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Yield: ∼35% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Ni (1271.17): C, 37.79; H, 2.22; N, 8.82%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.72; N, 8.71%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3044m, 2462w, 1942w, 1606s, 1538s, 1394s, 1326w, 1229s, 1065m, 922s, 819s, 675s, 518s.
elements.clean_text: The preparation procedure of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) was used instead of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Yield: ~35% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Ni (1271.17): C, 37.79; H, 2.22; N, 8.82%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.72; N, 8.71%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3044m, 2462w, 1942w, 1606s, 1538s, 1394s, 1326w, 1229s, 1065m, 922s, 819s, 675s, 518s.

elements.content: The 1 - and 2 -modified carbon paste electrodes (1 -CPE and 2-CPE) were prepared by the following method: 0.05 g of complex 1 or 2 and 0.5 g of graphite powder were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle for approximately 20 min to achieve a uniform mixture, dry mixture; 0.20 mL of paraffin oil was added and the mixture was stirred with a glass rod; then the homogenized mixture was used to pack 3 mm inner diameter glass tubes to a length of 0.8 cm. The electrical contact was established with the copper stick, and the surface of 1-CPE and 2 -CPE was wiped with weighing paper. The bare carbon paste electrode was prepared by the same procedure as described above except that the modifier was not added.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 1-CPE and 2-CPE

The 1 - and 2 -modified carbon paste electrodes (1 -CPE and 2-CPE) were prepared by the following method: 0.05 g of complex 1 or 2 and 0.5 g of graphite powder were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle for approximately 20 min to achieve a uniform mixture, dry mixture; 0.20 mL of paraffin oil was added and the mixture was stirred with a glass rod; then the homogenized mixture was used to pack 3 mm inner diameter glass tubes to a length of 0.8 cm. The electrical contact was established with the copper stick, and the surface of 1-CPE and 2 -CPE was wiped with weighing paper. The bare carbon paste electrode was prepared by the same procedure as described above except that the modifier was not added.

elements.content: In the process of photocatalysis, 98 mg of complex 1 or 2 was suspended in 350 mL of MO or RhB aqueous solution of 1.83 × 10–5 mol/L, and then magnetically stirred in the dark for about 30 min, respectively. After that, the mixture was stirred and continuously exposed to UV irradiation from a 500 W high pressure mercury vapor lamp. The sample of a certain volume was taken every 30 min from the vessel, and subsequently analyzed by UV–vis spectroscopy. There has a faster rate of removal of organic dye from solution owing to its adsorption to the particle surfaces at first. Thus, the first 30 min of the photocatalytic reaction was not included in the rate calculation.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Experiments

In the process of photocatalysis, 98 mg of complex 1 or 2 was suspended in 350 mL of MO or RhB aqueous solution of 1.83 × 10-5 mol/L, and then magnetically stirred in the dark for about 30 min, respectively. After that, the mixture was stirred and continuously exposed to UV irradiation from a 500 W high pressure mercury vapor lamp. The sample of a certain volume was taken every 30 min from the vessel, and subsequently analyzed by UV-vis spectroscopy. There has a faster rate of removal of organic dye from solution owing to its adsorption to the particle surfaces at first. Thus, the first 30 min of the photocatalytic reaction was not included in the rate calculation.

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of two complexes, the XRPD pattern was characterized. As shown in , the experimental XRPD patterns of 1 and 2 are in good agreement with their corresponding simulated patterns, indicating phase purity of two samples.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD

In order to confirm the phase purity of two complexes, the XRPD pattern was characterized. As shown in , the experimental XRPD patterns of 1 and 2 are in good agreement with their corresponding simulated patterns, indicating phase purity of two samples.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. The atoms O2, O7, and Mo2 in 2 were disposed by the disorder method and were restrained using thermal restraints (isor) to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. The crystal data and structure refinement details for 1 and 2 are given in Table . The data of relevant bond distances and angles are listed in . The CCDC reference numbers are 887835 and 887836 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. The atoms O2, O7, and Mo2 in 2 were disposed by the disorder method and were restrained using thermal restraints (isor) to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. The crystal data and structure refinement details for 1 and 2 are given in Table . The data of relevant bond distances and angles are listed in . The CCDC reference numbers are 887835 and 887836 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content:
Crystal Data and Structure Refinement Parameters for <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> 1 2 formula C40H28N8O13Mo4Cu C40H28N8O13Mo4Ni fw 1276.00 1271.17 space group P1̅ P1̅ a [Å] 8.1754(2) 8.1234(16) b [Å] 9.3313(2) 8.9511(18) c [Å] 13.893(3) 14.020(3) α [°] 78.35(3) 79.16(3) β [°] 83.15(3) 84.09(3) γ [°] 76.44(3) 78.23(3) V (Å 3) 1006.2(3) 978.0(3) Z 1 1 F(000) 625 624 μ/mm–1 1.812 1.802 R/wR [I > 2σ(I)] 0.0468/0.0964 0.1131/0.2664 GOF on F 2 1.067 1.070

R = Σ(∥F 0| – |F C∥)/Σ|F 0| wR2 = [Σw(|F 0|2 – |F C|2)2/(Σw|F 0|2)2]1/2.

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complexes 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in space group P1̅ (see Table). As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cu(II) ion, one Mo4O13 2– anion, and two pytpy ligands. Each Cu(II) ion is tetra-coordinated by two μ2-bridging oxygen atoms [Cu–O 1.945(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms of pytpy [Cu–N 2.028(5) Å], which displays a distorted square coordination environment. There are two crystallographically independent Mo(VI) ions assuming different coordination geometry. Mo1 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, defined by three μ2-bridging oxygen atoms and one terminal oxygen atom [Mo–O 1.698(5)–1.805(4) Å]. However, Mo2 shows a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by three μ2-bridging oxygen atoms, two terminal oxygen atoms, and one nitrogen atom of pytpy [Mo–O 1.682(4)–2.201(4) Å, Mo–N 2.442(5) Å]. Thus, two types of coordination configurations, tetrahedral {MoO4} and octahedral {MoO5N}, were observed for Mo(VI) ions in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structures

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complexes 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in space group P1̅ (see Table). As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cu(II) ion, one Mo4O13 2- anion, and two pytpy ligands. Each Cu(II) ion is tetra-coordinated by two μ2-bridging oxygen atoms [Cu-O 1.945(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms of pytpy [Cu-N 2.028(5) Å], which displays a distorted square coordination environment. There are two crystallographically independent Mo(VI) ions assuming different coordination geometry. Mo1 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, defined by three μ2-bridging oxygen atoms and one terminal oxygen atom [Mo-O 1.698(5)-1.805(4) Å]. However, Mo2 shows a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by three μ2-bridging oxygen atoms, two terminal oxygen atoms, and one nitrogen atom of pytpy [Mo-O 1.682(4)-2.201(4) Å, Mo-N 2.442(5) Å]. Thus, two types of coordination configurations, tetrahedral {MoO4} and octahedral {MoO5N}, were observed for Mo(VI) ions in 1.

elements.content: The coordination environments of metal ions in 1 with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  The coordination environments of metal ions in 1 with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In complex 1, four neighboring Mo(VI) ions are connected by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms to form a Mo4O13 2– subunit. Meanwhile, the Mo4O13 2– units are linked by the μ2-bridging O2 atoms, forming a 1D chain structure (Figure S1, ). Furthermore, the adjacent oxomolybdenum chains connect Cu(II) ions through terminal oxygen atoms to generate a heterometal-oxide inorganic layer (Figure S1b, ). It is noteworthy that the pytpy ligands are distributed alternately between the 2D layers. Finally, the 2D network is pillared by the pytpy, which leads to the formation of a 3D pillar-layer framework (Figure ). To our knowledge, one non-oxygen-bound ligand is coordinated directly to a molybdenum ion and the second metal ion simultaneously is rare in Mo-POM-based hybrids. It should be pointed out that the molybdenum-oxide building block and the structure of complex 1 were very different from the related complex {[Ni(L)2(H2O)][γ-Mo8O26]0.5·H2O} n (L = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane) reported by Wang et al., in which the building unit is the normal Mo8O26 4– and adopts the tetra-coordinated mode. Another important structural feature of complex 1 is that it possesses an array (Figure ) through the π–π stacking interactions (Cg–Cg, distance between ring centroids, is in the range of 3.526(4)–3.762(4) Å, and the dihedral angles are between 0 to 1.8°), which plays a significant role in the stabilization of the framework.
elements.clean_text: In complex 1, four neighboring Mo(VI) ions are connected by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms to form a Mo4O13 2- subunit. Meanwhile, the Mo4O13 2- units are linked by the μ2-bridging O2 atoms, forming a 1D chain structure (Figure S1, ). Furthermore, the adjacent oxomolybdenum chains connect Cu(II) ions through terminal oxygen atoms to generate a heterometal-oxide inorganic layer (Figure S1b, ). It is noteworthy that the pytpy ligands are distributed alternately between the 2D layers. Finally, the 2D network is pillared by the pytpy, which leads to the formation of a 3D pillar-layer framework (Figure ). To our knowledge, one non-oxygen-bound ligand is coordinated directly to a molybdenum ion and the second metal ion simultaneously is rare in Mo-POM-based hybrids. It should be pointed out that the molybdenum-oxide building block and the structure of complex 1 were very different from the related complex {[Ni(L)2(H2O)][γ-Mo8O26]0.5⋅H2O} n  (L = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane) reported by Wang et al., in which the building unit is the normal Mo8O26 4- and adopts the tetra-coordinated mode. Another important structural feature of complex 1 is that it possesses an array (Figure ) through the π-π stacking interactions (Cg-Cg, distance between ring centroids, is in the range of 3.526(4)-3.762(4) Å, and the dihedral angles are between 0 to 1.8°), which plays a significant role in the stabilization of the framework.

elements.content: The 3D “pillar-layer” structure generated by the heterometal-oxide inorganic layer and the pillar pytpy along the b axis (a) (left: the 1D supramolecular pytpy chain); along the c axis (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  The 3D "pillar-layer" structure generated by the heterometal-oxide inorganic layer and the pillar pytpy along the b axis (a) (left: the 1D supramolecular pytpy chain); along the c axis (b).

elements.content: To provide further insight into the structure of 1, it is necessary to simplify the node-and-linker reference nets from the topological point of view. We can consider the Cu(II) ions as 4-connected nodes (Schlafli symbol is 64.102) and assume that the Mo1 (Schlafli symbol is 4.62) and Mo2 (Schlafli symbol is 4.62.83) are distinguished. As a result, the overall 3D networks of 1 can be rationalized as a trinodal (3,4,4)-connected net with Schläfli symbol {4.62.83}2{4.62}2{64.102} (topological type is 3,4,4T20) (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: To provide further insight into the structure of 1, it is necessary to simplify the node-and-linker reference nets from the topological point of view. We can consider the Cu(II) ions as 4-connected nodes (Schlafli symbol is 64.102) and assume that the Mo1 (Schlafli symbol is 4.62) and Mo2 (Schlafli symbol is 4.62.83) are distinguished. As a result, the overall 3D networks of 1 can be rationalized as a trinodal (3,4,4)-connected net with Schläfli symbol {4.62.83}2{4.62}2{64.102} (topological type is 3,4,4T20) (Figure ).

elements.content: (a) The trinodal 3,4,4-connected 3D framework with Schläfli symbol {4.62.83}2{4.62}2{64.102}; (b) the tiling structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The trinodal 3,4,4-connected 3D framework with Schläfli symbol {4.62.83}2{4.62}2{64.102}; (b) the tiling structure of 1.

elements.content: For complex 2, the asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) ion, one Mo4O13 2– anion, and two pytpy ligands similar to that of 1. As shown in Figure , all Ni(II) ions are hexa-coordinated by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms [Ni–O 2.041(1)–2.186(1) Å] and two nitrogen atoms of pytpy [Ni–N 2.036(1) Å], which displays a distorted octahedral coordination environment. However, the coordination environments of Mo(VI) ions are completely identical in the two complexes [Mo–O 1.660(3)–2.158(1) Å; Mo–N 2.457(1) Å].
elements.clean_text: For complex 2, the asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) ion, one Mo4O13 2- anion, and two pytpy ligands similar to that of 1. As shown in Figure , all Ni(II) ions are hexa-coordinated by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms [Ni-O 2.041(1)-2.186(1) Å] and two nitrogen atoms of pytpy [Ni-N 2.036(1) Å], which displays a distorted octahedral coordination environment. However, the coordination environments of Mo(VI) ions are completely identical in the two complexes [Mo-O 1.660(3)-2.158(1) Å; Mo-N 2.457(1) Å].

elements.content: The coordination environments of metal ions in 2 with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  The coordination environments of metal ions in 2 with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Similar to complex 1, a 1D chain structure based on Mo4O13 2– units was also observed in 2. Furthermore, the Ni(II) ions are well assembled by the adjacent oxomolybdenum chains to form a 2D heterometal-oxide inorganic network (Figure S2a, ). Therefore, the 2D layers are further extended into an interesting 3D framework pillared by pytpy (Figure a). In addition, the π–π stacking interactions are also observed between pytpy ligands (Cg–Cg, distance between ring centroids, is in the range of 3.404(9)–3.526(9) Å, and the dihedral angles are between 0 to 1.51°) (Figure S2b, ). If we regard the pytpy ligands and μ2-bridging oxygen atoms as spacers, the total framework of 2 can be considered as a (3,5,6)-connected (42.6)2(44.66)2(44.68.83) topology (Figure b). To our knowledge, such a net has not been reported before. Obviously, as far as complexes 1 and 2 are concerned, the different coordination numbers of Cu(II) and Ni(II) ions are the most critical factors in determining the final topology structures of the two complexes.
elements.clean_text: Similar to complex 1, a 1D chain structure based on Mo4O13 2- units was also observed in 2. Furthermore, the Ni(II) ions are well assembled by the adjacent oxomolybdenum chains to form a 2D heterometal-oxide inorganic network (Figure S2a, ). Therefore, the 2D layers are further extended into an interesting 3D framework pillared by pytpy (Figure a). In addition, the π-π stacking interactions are also observed between pytpy ligands (Cg-Cg, distance between ring centroids, is in the range of 3.404(9)-3.526(9) Å, and the dihedral angles are between 0 to 1.51°) (Figure S2b, ). If we regard the pytpy ligands and μ2-bridging oxygen atoms as spacers, the total framework of 2 can be considered as a (3,5,6)-connected (42.6)2(44.66)2(44.68.83) topology (Figure b). To our knowledge, such a net has not been reported before. Obviously, as far as complexes 1 and 2 are concerned, the different coordination numbers of Cu(II) and Ni(II) ions are the most critical factors in determining the final topology structures of the two complexes.

elements.content: (a) The 3D “pillar-layer” structure of 2; (b) the trinodal 3,5,6-connected topology.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) The 3D "pillar-layer" structure of 2; (b) the trinodal 3,5,6-connected topology.

elements.content: POMs’ ability to undergo reversible multielectron redox processes has been exploited extensively in electrocatalytic reductions. Owing to the poor solubility of the POMs-based hybrids in water and common organic solvents, complexes 1–2 bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) were fabricated as the working electrode to investigate their electrochemical property.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Behavior

POMs' ability to undergo reversible multielectron redox processes has been exploited extensively in electrocatalytic reductions. Owing to the poor solubility of the POMs-based hybrids in water and common organic solvents, complexes 1-2 bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) were fabricated as the working electrode to investigate their electrochemical property.

elements.content: Figure a shows the cyclic voltammetric behaviors of 1–CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution. There are two reversible redox peaks in the potential range of 100–700 mV attributable to the molybdenum with mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 at 167 and 321 mV (scan rate: 200 mV/s). As can be seen from , the peak currents are proportional to the scan rates, indicating that the redox process of 1–CPE is surface-controlled. With the addition of nitrite, all of the reduction peak currents increase markedly while the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease gradually (Figure b), which indicated that 1–CPE has good electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of nitrite.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows the cyclic voltammetric behaviors of 1-CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution. There are two reversible redox peaks in the potential range of 100-700 mV attributable to the molybdenum with mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 at 167 and 321 mV (scan rate: 200 mV/s). As can be seen from , the peak currents are proportional to the scan rates, indicating that the redox process of 1-CPE is surface-controlled. With the addition of nitrite, all of the reduction peak currents increase markedly while the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease gradually (Figure b), which indicated that 1-CPE has good electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of nitrite.

elements.content: (a) Cyclic voltammograms of 1–CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution at different scan rates (from inner to outer: 80, 120, 140, 160, 180, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, and 500 mV/s); (b) cyclic voltammograms of 1–CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution containing 0.0–8.0 mM KNO2 and a bare CPE in a 4.0 mM KNO2 + 1 M H2SO4 solution. Scan rate: 120 mV/s.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Cyclic voltammograms of 1-CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution at different scan rates (from inner to outer: 80, 120, 140, 160, 180, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, and 500 mV/s); (b) cyclic voltammograms of 1-CPE in a 1 M H2SO4 solution containing 0.0-8.0 mM KNO2 and a bare CPE in a 4.0 mM KNO2 + 1 M H2SO4 solution. Scan rate: 120 mV/s.

elements.content: The cyclic voltammetric behaviors and electrocatalytic performance in the reduction of nitrite were also measured for 2–CPE (Figure S5, ), with electrocatalytic activity similar to that of 1–CPE. The slight potential shifts of redox peaks measured with 2–CPE relative to that with 1–CPE can be ascribed to different central-metal ion category between these two complexes.
elements.clean_text: The cyclic voltammetric behaviors and electrocatalytic performance in the reduction of nitrite were also measured for 2-CPE (Figure S5, ), with electrocatalytic activity similar to that of 1-CPE. The slight potential shifts of redox peaks measured with 2-CPE relative to that with 1-CPE can be ascribed to different central-metal ion category between these two complexes.

elements.content: Methyl orange (MO) and rhodamine B (RhB) are often used as models of dye pollutant to evaluate the effectiveness of photocatalysts in the purification of wastewater. The goal of photocatalytic degradation is to decompose the organic dye into nonpolluting small molecules such as small organic acids and CO2. During the photocatalytic process of POM-based inorganic–organic hybrids, UV–vis light induces POM/organic ligands (L) to produce oxygen and/or nitrogen–metal charge transfer with promoting electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The charge transfer excited state (POM* and/or L*) can be deactivated by oxidizing the contaminant directly, and/or oxygenating water molecules into the •OH radicals, to complete the photocatalytic process.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Activity

Methyl orange (MO) and rhodamine B (RhB) are often used as models of dye pollutant to evaluate the effectiveness of photocatalysts in the purification of wastewater. The goal of photocatalytic degradation is to decompose the organic dye into nonpolluting small molecules such as small organic acids and CO2. During the photocatalytic process of POM-based inorganic-organic hybrids, UV-vis light induces POM/organic ligands (L) to produce oxygen and/or nitrogen-metal charge transfer with promoting electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The charge transfer excited state (POM* and/or L*) can be deactivated by oxidizing the contaminant directly, and/or oxygenating water molecules into the ⋅OH radicals, to complete the photocatalytic process.

elements.content: Two hybrids are water-insoluble; the photocatalytic activities of as-prepared 1 and 2 were tested by the degradation of MO and RhB aqueous solutions under UV light irradiation, respectively. For comparison, the photodegradation process of MO or RhB solutions without any photocatalyst were also studied under the same conditions (Figure S6, ). As illustrated in Figure , the absorbances decreased and the changes in the concentration (C t /C0) of MO and RhB solutions were plotted versus irradiation time with using complex 1 as photocatalyst. It can be seen that approximately 68.8% of MO and approximately 13% of RhB have been decomposed after 3 h of irradiation, and the degradation rates are 23 × 10–2 h–1 and 4.3 × 10–2 h–1, respectively. These results indicated that catalyst 1 is more active for the decomposition of MO under UV light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: Two hybrids are water-insoluble; the photocatalytic activities of as-prepared 1 and 2 were tested by the degradation of MO and RhB aqueous solutions under UV light irradiation, respectively. For comparison, the photodegradation process of MO or RhB solutions without any photocatalyst were also studied under the same conditions (Figure S6, ). As illustrated in Figure , the absorbances decreased and the changes in the concentration (C  t  /C0) of MO and RhB solutions were plotted versus irradiation time with using complex 1 as photocatalyst. It can be seen that approximately 68.8% of MO and approximately 13% of RhB have been decomposed after 3 h of irradiation, and the degradation rates are 23 × 10-2 h-1 and 4.3 × 10-2 h-1, respectively. These results indicated that catalyst 1 is more active for the decomposition of MO under UV light irradiation.

elements.content: Absorption spectra of the MO (a) and RhB (b) solutions during the decomposition reaction catalyzed by complex 1; photocatalytic decomposition of MO (c) and RhB (d) solutions under UV light irradiation of 1. (C t and C 0 stand for the MO or RhB concentrations after and before irradiation.)
elements.clean_text: 7  Absorption spectra of the MO (a) and RhB (b) solutions during the decomposition reaction catalyzed by complex 1; photocatalytic decomposition of MO (c) and RhB (d) solutions under UV light irradiation of 1. (C  t  and C 0 stand for the MO or RhB concentrations after and before irradiation.)

elements.content: For 2, the UV absorption spectra and the plot of C t /C 0 of MO and RhB solutions versus irradiation time are shown in Figure . After 3 h, the C t /C 0 of MO degrades from 100% to 18.1% with a degradation rate of 27 × 10–2 h–1. However, the degradation of RhB is approximately 14% in the same time with the degradation rate of 4.6 × 10–2 h–1. Thus, complex 2 also has a high photocatalytic activity for the degradation of MO.
elements.clean_text: For 2, the UV absorption spectra and the plot of C  t  /C 0 of MO and RhB solutions versus irradiation time are shown in Figure . After 3 h, the C  t  /C 0 of MO degrades from 100% to 18.1% with a degradation rate of 27 × 10-2 h-1. However, the degradation of RhB is approximately 14% in the same time with the degradation rate of 4.6 × 10-2 h-1. Thus, complex 2 also has a high photocatalytic activity for the degradation of MO.

elements.content: Absorption spectra of the MO (a) and RhB (b) solutions during the decomposition reaction in the presence of 2; photocatalytic decomposition of MO (c) and RhB (d) solutions with the changes in C t /C 0 versus irradiation time plot of 2. (C t and C 0 stand for the MO or RhB concentrations after and before irradiation.)
elements.clean_text: 8  Absorption spectra of the MO (a) and RhB (b) solutions during the decomposition reaction in the presence of 2; photocatalytic decomposition of MO (c) and RhB (d) solutions with the changes in C  t  /C 0 versus irradiation time plot of 2. (C  t  and C 0 stand for the MO or RhB concentrations after and before irradiation.)

elements.content: On the basis of above photocatalytic results, we can see that complexes 1 and 2 have an enormous advantage during the photocatalytic decomposition of MO compared to RhB under the identical photocatalytic process and concentration (Figure ). It is noted that approximately 25% of MO has been decomposed during the first 30 min with using 2 as photocatalyst, which indicated that 2 is more effective than 1 in photocatalytic decomposition of MO. Moreover, the BET surface areas of 1 and 2 were 0.59, and 0.66 m2 g–1, respectively. The relative activity for two complexes might be caused by different BET surface areas. The photocatalytic degradation of RhB solution is not obviously observed, implying no photocatalytic activity of two complexes under UV. It is clear that two complexes possessed higher activity for MO than RhB; however, the detailed reason is difficult to explain at the current stage. It could be mainly attributed to the π–π* transition of organic ligands in the UV region and different metal centers.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of above photocatalytic results, we can see that complexes 1 and 2 have an enormous advantage during the photocatalytic decomposition of MO compared to RhB under the identical photocatalytic process and concentration (Figure ). It is noted that approximately 25% of MO has been decomposed during the first 30 min with using 2 as photocatalyst, which indicated that 2 is more effective than 1 in photocatalytic decomposition of MO. Moreover, the BET surface areas of 1 and 2 were 0.59, and 0.66 m2 g-1, respectively. The relative activity for two complexes might be caused by different BET surface areas. The photocatalytic degradation of RhB solution is not obviously observed, implying no photocatalytic activity of two complexes under UV. It is clear that two complexes possessed higher activity for MO than RhB; however, the detailed reason is difficult to explain at the current stage. It could be mainly attributed to the π-π* transition of organic ligands in the UV region and different metal centers.

elements.content: The degradation rates of MO and RhB solutions for 1 and 2 under the same photodegradation conditions.
elements.clean_text: 9  The degradation rates of MO and RhB solutions for 1 and 2 under the same photodegradation conditions.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the reproducibility of complexes 1 and 2, the repeated photocatalysis experiment was also studied with a constant MO concentration. After each cycle of MO photodegradation, complex 1 or 2 was separated by centrifugation and washed with water. As shown in , no significant reduction of decolorization rate was observed during the reusing of photocatalysts up to five times under the same photodegradation condition. This result indicates that the photocatalytic activities of 1 and 2 are reproducible. After photocatalysis, XRPD patterns of 1 and 2 were nearly identical to that of the original complexes, indicating that the basic framework remains unchanged (). All in all, the good photocatalytic activity and reproducibility are important features for complexes 1 and 2 used as photocatalysts.
elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the reproducibility of complexes 1 and 2, the repeated photocatalysis experiment was also studied with a constant MO concentration. After each cycle of MO photodegradation, complex 1 or 2 was separated by centrifugation and washed with water. As shown in , no significant reduction of decolorization rate was observed during the reusing of photocatalysts up to five times under the same photodegradation condition. This result indicates that the photocatalytic activities of 1 and 2 are reproducible. After photocatalysis, XRPD patterns of 1 and 2 were nearly identical to that of the original complexes, indicating that the basic framework remains unchanged (). All in all, the good photocatalytic activity and reproducibility are important features for complexes 1 and 2 used as photocatalysts.

elements.content: Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic–organic hybrid materials containing the pure heterometal-oxide inorganic layers have been successfully obtained. They present 3D “pillar-layer” frameworks where the inorganic layer was pillared by pytpy, and the frameworks of the two complexes can be simplified into different topologies because of the different coordination numbers of Cu(II) and Ni(II) ions. Furthermore, the two complexes, especially complex 2, show good photocatalytic activities for the decomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV–vis light irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two water-insoluble isostructural inorganic-organic hybrid materials containing the pure heterometal-oxide inorganic layers have been successfully obtained. They present 3D "pillar-layer" frameworks where the inorganic layer was pillared by pytpy, and the frameworks of the two complexes can be simplified into different topologies because of the different coordination numbers of Cu(II) and Ni(II) ions. Furthermore, the two complexes, especially complex 2, show good photocatalytic activities for the decomposition of methyl orange (MO) solution under UV-vis light irradiation.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 in CIF format, selected bond lengths and angles, general characterizations (XRPD, IR, and TGA), and additional structure figures. These materials are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 in CIF format, selected bond lengths and angles, general characterizations (XRPD, IR, and TGA), and additional structure figures. These materials are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.2 mg), H3PMo12·xH2O (∼0.05 mmol,100 mg), and pytpy (0.2 mmol, 62 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The pH value was adjusted to 2.6–3.2 with 1 M NaOH solution, and then the mixture was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon reactor autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, blue needle crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. Yield: ∼40% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Cu (1276.00): C, 37.65; H, 2.21; N, 8.78%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.48; N, 8.53%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3044m, 2455w, 1934w, 1600s, 1531s, 1401s, 1318w, 1216s, 922s, 825s, 695s, 531s.

The preparation procedure of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) was used instead of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Yield: ∼35% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Ni (1271.17): C, 37.79; H, 2.22; N, 8.82%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.72; N, 8.71%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3044m, 2462w, 1942w, 1606s, 1538s, 1394s, 1326w, 1229s, 1065m, 922s, 819s, 675s, 518s.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [M(pytpy)2Mo4O13]∞ (M = Cu 1, Ni 2)

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.2 mg), H3PMo12⋅xH2O (~0.05 mmol,100 mg), and pytpy (0.2 mmol, 62 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The pH value was adjusted to 2.6-3.2 with 1 M NaOH solution, and then the mixture was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon reactor autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, blue needle crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. Yield: ~40% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Cu (1276.00): C, 37.65; H, 2.21; N, 8.78%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.48; N, 8.53%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3044m, 2455w, 1934w, 1600s, 1531s, 1401s, 1318w, 1216s, 922s, 825s, 695s, 531s.

The preparation procedure of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) was used instead of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Yield: ~35% based on pytpy. Anal. Calc. for C40H28N8O13Mo4Ni (1271.17): C, 37.79; H, 2.22; N, 8.82%. Found: C, 37.09; H, 2.72; N, 8.71%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3044m, 2462w, 1942w, 1606s, 1538s, 1394s, 1326w, 1229s, 1065m, 922s, 819s, 675s, 518s.

cln_elements.content:
Two hybrids are water-insoluble; the photocatalytic activities of as-prepared 1 and 2 were tested by the degradation of MO and RhB aqueous solutions under UV light irradiation, respectively. For comparison, the photodegradation process of MO or RhB solutions without any photocatalyst were also studied under the same conditions (Figure S6, ). As illustrated in Figure , the absorbances decreased and the changes in the concentration (C t /C0) of MO and RhB solutions were plotted versus irradiation time with using complex 1 as photocatalyst. It can be seen that approximately 68.8% of MO and approximately 13% of RhB have been decomposed after 3 h of irradiation, and the degradation rates are 23 × 10–2 h–1 and 4.3 × 10–2 h–1, respectively. These results indicated that catalyst 1 is more active for the decomposition of MO under UV light irradiation.

On the basis of above photocatalytic results, we can see that complexes 1 and 2 have an enormous advantage during the photocatalytic decomposition of MO compared to RhB under the identical photocatalytic process and concentration (Figure ). It is noted that approximately 25% of MO has been decomposed during the first 30 min with using 2 as photocatalyst, which indicated that 2 is more effective than 1 in photocatalytic decomposition of MO. Moreover, the BET surface areas of 1 and 2 were 0.59, and 0.66 m2 g–1, respectively. The relative activity for two complexes might be caused by different BET surface areas. The photocatalytic degradation of RhB solution is not obviously observed, implying no photocatalytic activity of two complexes under UV. It is clear that two complexes possessed higher activity for MO than RhB; however, the detailed reason is difficult to explain at the current stage. It could be mainly attributed to the π–π* transition of organic ligands in the UV region and different metal centers.

It can be seen that approximately 68.8% of MO and approximately 13% of RhB have been decomposed after 3 h of irradiation, and the degradation rates are 23 × 10-2 h-1 and 4.3 × 10-2 h-1, respectively. These results indicated that catalyst 1 is more active for the decomposition of MO under UV light irradiation.

On the basis of above photocatalytic results, we can see that complexes 1 and 2 have an enormous advantage during the photocatalytic decomposition of MO compared to RhB under the identical photocatalytic process and concentration (Figure ). It is noted that approximately 25% of MO has been decomposed during the first 30 min with using 2 as photocatalyst, which indicated that 2 is more effective than 1 in photocatalytic decomposition of MO. The photocatalytic degradation of RhB solution is not obviously observed, implying no photocatalytic activity of two complexes under UV. It is clear that two complexes possessed higher activity for MO than RhB; however, the detailed reason is difficult to explain at the current stage. It could be mainly attributed to the π-π* transition of organic ligands in the UV region and different metal centers.

metadata.title:
Water-Insoluble Heterometal-Oxide-Based Photocatalysts
Effective for the Photo-Decomposition of Methyl Orange
